Dataset s𝑠s non-i.i.d. index (p𝑝p)

MNIST 0 92.69 89.49 86.17 84.49
2 92.64 89.11 86.54 71.58

CIFAR-10 0 81.12 79.42 78.22 75.7
2 79.97 78.54 76.68 64.56

references:
1) Performance Degradation of Incomplete Client Participation:
As shown in Table 1, a distinct and non-trivial decline in performance is observed for FedAvg when confronted with incomplete client participation.
As the value of s𝑠s increases, it signifies progressively more incomplete client participation.
Upon comparing scenarios with s=0𝑠0s=0 and s=4𝑠4s=4 , a significant reduction in test accuracy becomes apparent, reaching up to 27.44%percent27.4427.44\% for MNIST and 25%percent2525\% for CIFAR10.
It is noteworthy that such performance degradation is also contingent on data heterogeneity, denoted by p𝑝p. In the case of IID data (p=10𝑝10p=10), only a negligible decrease in test accuracy is observed. For instance, in MNIST, the accuracy slightly drops from 92.69%percent92.6992.69\% for s=0𝑠0s=0 to 92.62%percent92.6292.62\% for s=4𝑠4s=4.
In CIFAR10, the accuracy decreases from 81.12%percent81.1281.12\% for s=0𝑠0s=0 to 77.78%percent77.7877.78\% for s=4𝑠4s=4.
These results empirically validate the worst-case analysis in Theorem 1 and serve as the primary motivation for the development of SA-FL.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2: Test accuracy improvement (%) for 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} (q=0.8𝑞0.8q=0.8) compared with FedAvg. ‘-’ means “no statistical difference within 2%percent22\% error bar”.
S5.T2.table:
Dataset s𝑠s non-i.i.d. index (p𝑝p)
10 5 2 1
MNIST 0 - - 3.13 4.47
2 - - 2.01 16.53
4 - - 10.69 31.07
CIFAR-10 0 - - - 2.57
2 - - - 12.57
4 - 2.93 9.32 23.86
references:
I. Improved test accuracy.
In Table 2 and  3, we show the test accuracy improvement of our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm compared with that of FedAvg in standard FL.
In Table 2, we can observe that even with a few server participation with a probability of 0.20.20.2, there is a non-negligible improvement in test accuracy.
In Table 3,
the key observation is that, with a small amount of auxiliary data at the server, there is a significant increase of test accuracy for our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm.
For example, with only 505050 data samples at the server (0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the total training data), there is a 16.65%percent16.6516.65\% test accuracy increase.
With 100010001000 data samples, the improvement reaches 31.07%percent31.0731.07\%.
This verifies the effectiveness of our SA-FL framework and our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm.
Another observation is that for nearly homogeneous case (e.g., from p=10𝑝10p=10 to p=5𝑝5p=5), there is no statistical difference with or without auxiliary data at the server (denoted by ‘-’ in Table 3.
This is consistent with the previous observations of negligible degradation in cases with homogeneous data across clients.

I. Improved test accuracy.
In Table 2 and  3, we show the test accuracy improvement of our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm compared with that of FedAvg in standard FL.
In Table 2, we can observe that even with a few server participation with a probability of 0.20.20.2, there is a non-negligible improvement in test accuracy.
In Table 3,
the key observation is that, with a small amount of auxiliary data at the server, there is a significant increase of test accuracy for our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm.
For example, with only 505050 data samples at the server (0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the total training data), there is a 16.65%percent16.6516.65\% test accuracy increase.
With 100010001000 data samples, the improvement reaches 31.07%percent31.0731.07\%.
This verifies the effectiveness of our SA-FL framework and our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm.
Another observation is that for nearly homogeneous case (e.g., from p=10𝑝10p=10 to p=5𝑝5p=5), there is no statistical difference with or without auxiliary data at the server (denoted by ‘-’ in Table 3.
This is consistent with the previous observations of negligible degradation in cases with homogeneous data across clients.

references: In Table 4, we show the comparison between our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm and FedAvg algorithm on CIFAR-10 for incomplete client participation s=4𝑠4s=4. The observations in Section 5 are further illustrated: 1) There is non-negligible increase of the test accuracy for 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm with small amount of auxiliary data at server’s side. With 10000 data at server’s side, the test accuracy increases by 23.86 %. 2) There is actually no improvement with these auxiliary data for nearly homogeneous case (e.g., p=10𝑝10p=10), which is denoted by ‘-’ in the table.

In Table 5, we show the test accuracy of 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} on MNIST and CIFAR-10 under different client update probability q𝑞q.

We can observe that even with a few server participation with a probability of 0.20.20.2, there is a non-negligible improvement in test accuracy.
